explanations.question: Why is dich used?
explanations.answer: "Dich" is the accusative form of "du" (you) in German. In this sentence, "warten auf" (to wait for) requires the accusative case for the object being waited for. Therefore, we use "dich" instead of "du".

explanations.question: Why is Im used here?
explanations.answer: "Im" is a contraction of "in dem," which is used to indicate a specific time or season in German. In this case, "im Frühling" means "in spring." The preposition "in" is used with the dative case when referring to seasons, hence "dem Frühling."
